overview: Extend algebraic concepts to advanced functions, complex numbers, conic sections, and statistical reasoning. Master polynomial, rational, exponential, and logarithmic relationships.
naturalProgression: Start with advanced function concepts—composition, inverses, and transformations build on Algebra 1 function basics
Deepen quadratic mastery with completing the square, vertex form, and complex number solutions
Explore polynomial functions through division, factoring theorems, and end behavior analysis
Master rational expressions and equations, connecting algebraic manipulation to graphical analysis with asymptotes
Extend exponent concepts to radicals and rational exponents as inverse operations
Build exponential and logarithmic reasoning as inverse function pairs with real-world modeling
Discover patterns in sequences and series, connecting arithmetic to linear and geometric to exponential
Investigate conic sections as geometric loci defined by distance relationships
Culminate with probability, counting, and the normal distribution—bridging algebra to statistics

aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads all instruction using the gradual release model (I Do / We Do / You Do) but has full freedom to make instructional decisions. Module files provide scope, key concepts, teaching guidance, and reference problems—NOT rigid scripts. The AI decides pacing, chooses examples, adjusts scaffolding, and personalizes based on the student's skill mastery, learning profile, and real-time responses.

phases.aiRole: Build conceptual understanding before procedures. The AI introduces the BIG IDEA using real-world connections, student interests, and visual/physical analogies. The AI chooses HOW to introduce based on the student's learning style.
phases.studentRole: Engage with the concept, ask questions, make predictions

phases.aiRole: Model 2-3 worked examples with think-aloud reasoning. The AI selects problem difficulty based on the student's current mastery and explains using the student's preferred style (visual, verbal, step-by-step, etc.).
phases.studentRole: Observe, ask clarifying questions, identify patterns

phases.aiRole: Quick comprehension check before moving to practice. The AI asks 1-2 targeted questions to verify the student grasps the concept, not just the procedure. If gaps detected, the AI re-teaches before proceeding.
phases.studentRole: Explain understanding in own words, answer concept questions

phases.aiRole: Guided practice with adaptive scaffolding. The AI provides problems and supports the student through them, offering hints ONLY when needed. Scaffolding decreases as the student demonstrates understanding. The AI decides when to move on.
phases.studentRole: Attempt problems with AI support, explain reasoning

phases.aiRole: Emotional and confidence assessment. The AI checks how the student FEELS about the material—not just accuracy. Adjusts pacing and tone based on anxiety, confidence, and engagement signals.
phases.studentRole: Reflect on confidence and comfort level

phases.aiRole: Independent practice. The AI presents problems and steps back, allowing the student to work independently. Minimal hints—only if the student is stuck. The AI evaluates accuracy, independence, and transfer.

Formal assessment for skill mastery. The AI determines if the student has met the 4-Pillar mastery criteria (accuracy, independence, transfer, retention). Awards mastery or identifies areas for re-teaching.

aiDecisionRights: Choose which examples and problems to present (module provides reference problems, AI may generate its own)
Adjust difficulty in real-time based on student performance
Skip or extend phases based on student readiness
Re-order skills within a module if pedagogically appropriate
Generate additional practice or enrichment as needed
Use student interests and learning profile to personalize examples
Decide when to advance to the next skill or re-teach
Select teaching strategies (visual, algebraic, numerical, verbal) based on student profile
Adjust tone and pacing based on emotional signals and anxiety level

modules.title: Functions & Inverses
modules.preview: Master function operations, composition, and inverses
essentialQuestions: How do function operations and composition create new relationships from existing ones?
What does it mean for functions to be inverses, and why is this concept so powerful?
How do transformations let us build complex graphs from simple parent functions?

lessons.title: Function Notation & Operations
lessons.teachingNotes: Review from Algebra 1 but extend to operations between functions. Emphasize domain restrictions for quotients.

lessons.title: Function Composition
commonMistakes: Not substituting the ENTIRE g(x) expression

lessons.title: Inverse Functions
concepts: One-to-one functions and horizontal line test
Finding inverses: swap x and y, solve for y
Verifying: f(f⁻¹(x)) = x and f⁻¹(f(x)) = x
Graphing inverses as reflections over y = x

lessons.title: Function Transformations
lessons.teachingNotes: Build a transformation toolkit that applies to ALL function families throughout the course.

modules.title: Advanced Quadratics
modules.preview: Completing the square, vertex form, complex solutions
essentialQuestions: How does completing the square reveal the vertex and provide a method to solve ANY quadratic?
What are complex numbers and why do we need them?
How does the discriminant determine the nature of solutions?

lessons.title: Completing the Square
concepts: Converting standard form to vertex form
Solving equations by completing the square
commonMistakes: Forgetting to balance when adding (b/2)² to both sides

lessons.title: Vertex Form & Graphing
concepts: Effect of a on width and direction

lessons.title: Complex Numbers
lessons.teachingNotes: Show the need for complex numbers through quadratics with negative discriminant.

lessons.title: The Discriminant & Complex Solutions
concepts: Two real solutions (D > 0), one repeated (D = 0), two complex (D < 0)
Writing complex solutions in a ± bi form
commonMistakes: Forgetting that complex solutions come in conjugate pairs

modules.title: Q1 Checkpoint
modules.preview: Functions, inverses, quadratics, and complex numbers

modules.title: Polynomial Functions
essentialQuestions: How is polynomial division analogous to numeric long division?
How do the Remainder and Factor Theorems connect evaluation, division, and factoring?
How does the degree and leading coefficient determine a polynomial's end behavior?

lessons.title: Polynomial Long Division
lessons.teachingNotes: Draw explicit parallel to numeric long division. Show side-by-side comparison.

lessons.title: Synthetic Division
concepts: Synthetic division as shortcut for (x - k) divisors
Setting up the synthetic division array
Reading quotient and remainder from the result

lessons.title: Remainder & Factor Theorems
concepts: Remainder Theorem: f(k) = remainder when dividing by (x - k)
Factor Theorem: (x - k) is a factor iff f(k) = 0

lessons.title: Graphing Polynomial Functions

commonMistakes: Confusing end behavior rules for odd vs even degree

modules.title: Rational Functions
modules.preview: Simplify expressions, solve equations, graph rational functions
essentialQuestions: Why must we factor before canceling, and what's the difference between canceling factors vs terms?
How do asymptotes and holes arise from the algebraic structure of a rational function?
Why do rational equations sometimes produce extraneous solutions?

lessons.title: Operations with Rational Expressions
concepts: Multiply: factor all, cancel, multiply across
Divide: flip second fraction, then multiply
Add/Subtract: find LCD, build equivalent fractions, combine
lessons.teachingNotes: Parallel to numeric fraction operations. Factor denominators first to find LCD.

lessons.title: Solving Rational Equations
concepts: Check for extraneous solutions (values that make original denominators zero)

lessons.title: Graphing Rational Functions
keyFormulas: deg(top) = deg(bottom): HA at y = leading coeff ratio

modules.title: Radicals & Rational Exponents
modules.preview: Simplify radicals, rational exponents, radical equations
essentialQuestions: How are radicals and rational exponents two notations for the same concept?
Why does √(a+b) ≠ √a + √b, and what operations DO distribute over radicals?
Why must we always check for extraneous solutions when solving radical equations?

lessons.title: Rational Exponents
concepts: All exponent rules apply to rational exponents

lessons.title: Simplifying Radical Expressions
concepts: Product and quotient properties of radicals

lessons.title: Solving Radical Equations
concepts: Raise both sides to appropriate power
CHECK all solutions for extraneous results

modules.title: Exponential & Logarithmic Functions

essentialQuestions: How are exponential and logarithmic functions inverses of each other?
How do properties of logarithms simplify complex expressions and equations?
How do exponential models describe growth and decay in the real world?

lessons.title: Exponential Functions Review & Extension
lessons.teachingNotes: Review from Algebra 1 but extend to base e and more complex transformations.

lessons.title: Introduction to Logarithms
concepts: Converting between exponential and log form
Common log (base 10) and natural log (base e)

lessons.title: Properties of Logarithms
commonMistakes: Forgetting that properties apply to multiplication/division only

lessons.title: Solving Exponential & Logarithmic Equations
concepts: Solving log equations by converting to exponential form

lessons.title: Exponential Growth & Decay Models

modules.title: Sequences & Series
modules.preview: Arithmetic and geometric sequences, summation notation
essentialQuestions: How are arithmetic sequences connected to linear functions and geometric sequences to exponential functions?
What conditions determine whether an infinite series converges to a finite sum?
How does sigma notation provide a compact way to express sums?

lessons.title: Arithmetic Sequences & Series
concepts: Arithmetic series sum: Sₙ = n(a₁ + aₙ)/2
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to linear functions: arithmetic sequence → linear graph. d is the slope.

lessons.title: Geometric Sequences & Series
concepts: Infinite geometric series: S∞ = a₁/(1-r) when |r| < 1

lessons.title: Sigma (Summation) Notation
concepts: Σ notation: index, lower bound, upper bound
Expanding sigma notation to write out terms
lessons.teachingNotes: Sigma is just shorthand. Practice going both directions: expand and condense.

modules.title: Conic Sections
essentialQuestions: How are all conic sections defined by distance relationships?
Why is completing the square the essential algebraic skill for working with conics?
How do the coefficients of a general second-degree equation determine which conic section it represents?

lessons.title: Circles
concepts: Converting general form to standard form via completing the square

lessons.title: Parabolas as Conic Sections
concepts: Parabola as locus of points equidistant from focus and directrix
lessons.teachingNotes: Connect to quadratic functions from Q1. The new concept is focus/directrix geometry.

lessons.title: Ellipses
commonMistakes: Confusing a and b (a is always larger)

lessons.title: Hyperbolas
concepts: c² = a² + b² (note: PLUS not minus)
Drawing the fundamental rectangle to find asymptotes

lessons.title: Identifying Conic Sections
concepts: General form: Ax² + Bxy + Cy² + Dx + Ey + F = 0

Converting general form to standard form
lessons.teachingNotes: This lesson ties everything together. Practice identifying and converting all four types.

modules.title: Probability & Statistics
modules.preview: Counting, permutations, combinations, probability, normal distribution
essentialQuestions: How does the fundamental counting principle form the basis for permutations and combinations?
How does the Binomial Theorem connect algebraic expansion to counting and probability?
How does the normal distribution model real-world variability?

lessons.title: Fundamental Counting Principle
lessons.teachingNotes: Build from concrete examples: outfits, menus, license plates.

lessons.title: Permutations & Combinations
concepts: Combinations: order doesn't matter, C(n,r) = n!/(r!(n-r)!)
Choosing which to use based on context

lessons.title: The Binomial Theorem

Finding specific terms in an expansion

aiGuidanceNotes: Algebra 2 extends and deepens all Algebra 1 concepts while introducing entirely new function families. The thread connecting everything is FUNCTIONS—every topic is a new function type with its own behavior, graph, and applications. Inverse relationships recur throughout: exponentials/logarithms, squaring/square roots, functions/inverses. Always connect new concepts to prior knowledge. Completing the square is a critical skill that appears in quadratics, conics, and beyond—ensure fluency early. For sequences and series, make the connection to linear (arithmetic) and exponential (geometric) functions explicit. End the course with probability and statistics to bridge toward AP Statistics and real-world data reasoning.
